exception.name: ErrorClientAlreadyRegistered
exception.description: This exception is thrown if the SE API function registerClient has already been invoked for the specific clientId. The clientId is therefore already registered. The function attempts to register a new client but detects that the provided clientId is already in use by another registered client.

javadoc.summary: This class defines the exception ErrorClientAlreadyRegistered that is thrown if the SE API function registerClient has already been invoked for the specific clientId. The clientId is therefore already registered.
javadoc.description: The ErrorClientAlreadyRegistered exception indicates that an attempt was made to register a client ID that has already been registered with the device. Each client ID must be unique within the device's client registry, and duplicate registration attempts violate this constraint. When this exception is raised, the registration operation fails immediately without modifying the client registry or device state. The application must choose a different clientId or deregister the existing client before attempting a new registration with the same ID.

specification.requirement: The exception ErrorClientAlreadyRegistered SHALL be raised if the passed clientId is already registered. The function registerClient SHALL check if the passed clientId is already registered. If the passed clientId is already registered, the function SHALL raise the exception ErrorClientAlreadyRegistered and exit the function without modifying any state. This ensures unique client identities within the device's client registry.
specification.applicability: Client registration operations - registerClient function only

condition.description: The registerClient function is invoked with a clientId that has already been successfully registered
condition.trigger: The application calls registerClient with a clientId that matches an existing registered client. The device checks the client registry and finds a matching clientId. This triggers ErrorClientAlreadyRegistered.

condition.scenario: Multiple registration attempts for same client
condition.description: An application attempts to register the same clientId multiple times without deregistering it first
condition.trigger: The first registerClient call with a given clientId succeeds and registers the client. Subsequent registerClient calls with the identical clientId fail with ErrorClientAlreadyRegistered.

notes.note: ErrorClientAlreadyRegistered is thrown ONLY by the registerClient function - it is specific to client registration operations
This exception enforces the uniqueness constraint of clientIds - each registered client must have a unique identifier

Unlike ErrorClientNotRegistered (which is raised when a function is invoked with an unregistered clientId), ErrorClientAlreadyRegistered is raised when attempting to register a clientId that already exists
After this exception, the client registry remains unchanged and the duplicate client is not added
This exception has Medium severity because it indicates a registration conflict but does not indicate a device or security failure
The duplicate check is performed early in the registerClient function (step 6), before other validation steps, to fail fast on this error condition
Applications must implement clientId uniqueness checks or be prepared to handle this exception when registration conflicts occur
The exception is raised by the device after checking its own client registry, providing authoritative feedback on duplicate registrations
If the application has deregistered a client, the clientId becomes available for reregistration and ErrorClientAlreadyRegistered will no longer be raised for that ID
Multiple clients cannot have the same ID - this exception ensures that constraint is enforced at the device level

scenario.name: Scenario 1: Duplicate Client Registration Attempt
scenario.description: An application attempts to register a client with a clientId that is already registered in the device. The registration fails immediately with ErrorClientAlreadyRegistered. The application catches the exception and either uses the existing registration or attempts deregistration first.
scenario.errorContext: Duplicate clientId - client already registered - conflict in client registry

scenario.name: Scenario 2: Client Re-Registration Without Deregistration
scenario.description: An application previously registered a client with a specific clientId. Without deregistering first, the application attempts to register again with the same clientId. The device detects the duplicate and raises ErrorClientAlreadyRegistered. Application must deregister first.
scenario.errorContext: Duplicate registration - client already active - deregistration required before re-registration

scenario.name: Scenario 3: Concurrent Registration Attempts
scenario.description: Multiple application threads or processes attempt to register clients simultaneously. Due to race conditions, both attempt to register with the same clientId. One succeeds, the other receives ErrorClientAlreadyRegistered. Application must implement synchronization.
scenario.errorContext: Race condition - concurrent registration attempts - synchronization needed

scenario.name: Scenario 4: Client Registry Persistence Check
scenario.description: Application checks the current registered clients using getRegisteredClients before attempting registration. This proactive approach can help avoid ErrorClientAlreadyRegistered by detecting duplicates before registration is attempted.
scenario.errorContext: Proactive duplicate detection - client registry query - conflict prevention

implementationContext.note: The registerClient function is part of the client management subsystem that tracks registered clients and their access to SE API functions
Each client must have a unique clientId within the device - duplicate clientIds are not permitted
The client registry is maintained by the device and enforces uniqueness constraints
Client registration is required before a client can perform transaction-related operations
A registered client can be deregistered to free up the clientId for potential future reuse
The clientId serves as the primary identifier for all client-related operations in transaction management
Applications should query getRegisteredClients before registration to avoid conflicts
Synchronization mechanisms should be implemented for multi-threaded client registration scenarios
The uniqueness check is performed at the Secure Element level to ensure consistency
ErrorClientAlreadyRegistered enforcement prevents clientId ambiguity in transaction logging and management
